content:
You find Etra Lash by the main tent of the festival grounds, sifting through a mess of carbonforged crates and featherweave sacks loaded onto a hoversled. He waves as you approach.
"Any luck gathering those flowers?" he asks. You nod and carefully arrange them onto a nearby table.
"These flowers are in excellent condition," Etra says, admiring your work. "You have a delicate touch. Thank you!"He beams with delight."Now to make the decorations!"
You weren't planning on spending the rest of the day making festival decorations, but such is the life of a Ranger. You begin to unfasten your pack when Etra stops you.
"I can ask no more of you, my friend," he says. "We have more than enough hands to arrange these flowers!"
You share a laugh and say your goodbyes, counting the days until the festival begins.

You're surprised to find this letter addressed to none other than your mentor.
Calypsa,
I'm writing to inform you of something that took place while Tiella and I were traveling east from the Biological Outpost. We took our usual route, making note of the Terravore's position and marking its progress, but while we were there, a rumbling from deep underground stopped us in our tracks. Normally I wouldn't be rattled by such an event—we've all felt tremors from time to time. But this gave me pause because I could swear it was coming from the Terravore itself, or perhaps just beneath it.
Might you be able to convince Elder Thrush to send a patrol into the Terravore to discern the cause? I would ask her myself, but I think that I may have lost some sway with her after the infamous bearsloth debacle, and an excursion into the mouth of the Terravore would be far more dangerous to say the least.
- Sirisana

You find Raemon waiting for you by the docks along the shore of White Sky Lake. A hoversled overstuffed with crates and barrels hums to life as you approach, lifting a quarter of a meter into the air.
"It's good to see you again!" he says. "You must be my Ranger escort." He shakes your hand again, his grip firm. "I've got all the supplies loaded and ready to go. Normally I wouldn't need the help, but something's got the cloudhive bees in a stir, and I don't want to take any chances. In any event, it should be a short journey to Brookside. I'm ready to leave when you are!"

Raemon gently taps the hoversled with his foot. When it doesn't respond, he gives it a firm kick. It sputters a few times, lifts a couple centimeters off the ground, then collapses once more.
"It's broken, all right," Raemon says with a sigh. "Could be the matter harmonizers, or even the molecular phase buffers. Regardless, we'll need to get some stilt-horses out here and tow it back to the artisan's workshop in White Sky for repairs."

When you reach Brookside, several volunteers rush to unload Raemon's hoversled. The Master of Revels, Etra Lash, watches the proceedings with a grim expression. "This doesn't look like everything. What happened?"
You explain that a few of the supplies were lost along the way, and he sighs. "I see. I suppose we'll have to send someone out to gather those abandoned supplies when we get the chance. Hopefully, we can find them! Until then, we'll have to make do."

When you reach Brookside, several volunteers rush over to unload Raemon's hoversled. Etra Lash, the Master of Revels, greets you with a smile, looking over the supplies you've delivered. You explain that a couple boxes went missing, but he doesn't seem too bothered by the news.
"We'll send someone out to gather those stray boxes when we get the chance," he says. "In the meantime, this should be enough to get us started. Thank you."

When you reach Brookside, several volunteers rush over to unload Raemon's hoversled. Etra Lash, the Master of Revels, greets you with a smile and claps you on the shoulder. "Just look at this bounty! And not a single thing missing!" he exclaims.
"If only I could have a Ranger escort every time," Raemon adds with a hearty chuckle. "I'd never worry about falling short on a delivery again!"

As you turn to leave, you notice Tiella Jakarra, who is usually stationed at the Biological Outpost, watching the proceedings with a troubled expression. You follow her gaze, and eventually spot several iridescent blue bees flitting about the tables where the festival supplies are set up.
Now that you think about it, you've been seeing quite a few cloudhive bees around, far more than usual. You ask Tiella if she's concerned about the presence of so many bees, and she nods absently.
"It's rare for cloudhives to be out this far from the shade of the old forests, but this out-of-season bloom has them on the move." Tiella looks on thoughtfully. "The cloudhive's behavior is predictable, but the circumstances of the bloom are undeniably strange."
After a moment, she continues. "Let's get to the bottom of it, shall we? I have a strong suspicion that the truth lies within the blooms themselves." She reaches into her pack and produces a small device—like a glass vial, with a stem and a brush-like tip extending from its center.
"This is a pollen brush," she says. "If you can collect some pollen for me, I can study it. Just dip this brush into an open flower and the pollen will be sucked into the vial. I'll be here in Brookside, cataloguing the bees' flight patterns and observing their behavior. What do you think?"
"The cloudhive itself must be nearby, so be on the lookout for swarms," she says. "Good luck!"

You meet up with Tiella and hand her the pollen you've collected. A strange, translucent-brown sludge has accumulated at the bottom of the vial, which she examines closely. "Well done," she says. "I think you may have found the cause of this unseasonal bloom."
You wait patiently as she scrapes the viscous liquid from the vial into a small dish, then dons a custom pair of hydrolens goggles set to maximum magnification. The sun travels far across the sky as she studies the contents of the dish, occasionally making notes in her journal. Finally, she takes off the goggles and invites you to look for yourself.
"I have a working theory," she says as the sample comes into microscopic view. "The liquid appears to the naked eye to be biological, but it's not. Do you see those subtle modifications in its cellular structure? I suspect that it's something the Estians concocted centuries ago to accelerate plant growth, and that it was somehow released into the environment once more. That would explain the bloom. There's a decent chance that the cloudhive bees themselves caused the spread of this compound, and now they're reaping the rewards. When the weather turns, and the cold rain comes, the bees will retreat to the warmth of their cloudhives and things should return to normal around here. Until then, we'll need to be wary of cloudhives appearing where they normally would not."
She hands you a glass cylinder with a spray nozzle. Inside, the thick brown liquid glimmers in the sunlight.
"Yet another gift from the Estians," she says."I don't know about you, but I can't wait to experiment with this stuff. Scientifically, of course."

You spot a small, tightly rolled correspondence scroll barely visible in the brush. You unroll it and see that it was originally addressed to Mae, the Ranger who writes the reports posted at the start of each week at every Ranger station in the Valley.
Really? More rain? My garden is practically drowning!
-Muddy in Meadow
Underneath that, a second person has written:
Dear Muddy,
I don't actually control the weather. You do know that, right?
—Mae
Needless to say, this isn't what you're looking for.

You are greeted first by the tantalizing aroma of fresh bakery, then seasoned fish and marinated meats cooking on sol coils, followed by a mouth-watering melange of spices and seasonings. You become hungry in an instant, as if you hadn't eaten in days.
The sound of conversation, laughter, and music fills the air. Children squeal with joy and waves of hearty cheers rise and fall.
If FESTIVAL SUPPLIES GATHERED:
 The festival grounds have been completely transformed since last you were here. What stands before you is a gathering on a scale of which you have rarely witnessed. It seems as though every last one of Spire's thousands of inhabitants have gathered upon Brookside's festival grounds. Many of them wear decorative floral necklaces, bracelets and anklets, bringing a splash of vivid color to their outfits.
The festivities (and the food) beckon as you gauge the position of the sun. You can only spend so much time away from your duties, so you'd better be prepared to make the most of it.

With a merry heart, you continue onward, and are greeted warmly by everyone you meet. Spirits are high, and you quickly learn of an enormous feast planned for later this evening. Until then there's plenty of time to celebrate with your friends and acquaintences, to enjoy the festival's many activities, and to sample its many delicacies, both savory and sweet.

You wake feeling refreshed and head straight to the festival in the light of the dawn. Already there are hundreds of people here enjoying the festivities and hundreds more following behind. The aroma of freshly brewed tea, honey rolls, and sizzling sausages beckons.
Spirits are high, and you quickly learn of an enormous feast planned for later this evening. Until then you have all day to spend with your friends and acquaintences, to enjoy the festival's many activities, and to sample its many delicacies, both savory and sweet.

As the hours pass and the feast draws near, you begin to notice more and more cloudhive bees buzzing about. One lands on the rim of your carbonforged cup and very nearly takes a swim in your sunberry wine. You set down your cup and start patrolling the grounds.
The bees are everywhere, mostly dancing in the air a few meters above the heads of festival-goers, but you notice more than one person swatting at the air or ducking for cover.
You spot Etra on his way to the front of the main tent, presumably to announce the start of the feast. Just then you hear a droning buzz in the distance, and a looming shadow begins to crawl over the festival grounds.
The sound grows and grows until it rises above even the clamor of the festival. A few people excitedly point to the sky, yelling in surprise. Your gaze snaps upward and it takes you a moment to comprehend what you're seeing.
What you first took for a small, dark cloud is actually the underside of a massive cloudhive, its bees gathered in ritualistic flight, holding it aloft, moving it steadily across the sky.
Someone yells in alarm, and the crowds scatter as a wide tornado of bees descends upon the festival grounds. Swarms terrorize the thoroughfares, gathering on the floral decorations, and on the food and drink, much of it still in the hands of fleeing villagers.
You call out to everyone to shed their floral jewelry, but it's not enough to stop the chaos. There's not a doubt in your mind; you have to find a way to get these bees out of here before they ruin the entire festival!

Try as you might, you're unable to repel the cloudhive. Countless bees swarm the festival grounds. Everyone has scattered.
The Blossom Festival has come to an abrupt and tragic end. What's worse, the cloudhive appears to be staying put, making Brookside its new home.

The aggressive, droning buzz of the cloudhive begins to falter, and you get the impression by the tenor of their song that the colony has decided that Brookside simply isn't worth the trouble. The beleaguered cloudhive slowly lifts into the sky and then retreats in the direction of the old growth forest to the south.
A great cheer rises up from the scattered crowd. The festival is saved.

The aggressive, droning buzz of the cloudhive suddenly turns to a low hum. As the sound persists, you get the impression that the bees of the cloudhive are in something of a discussion. Then, as if called to action, the bees infesting the grounds take to the sky and begin to gather around the hive.
Soon the hive becomes nearly invisible behind dark clouds of swarming bees. The sound of buzzing builds to a crescendo as the cloudhive raises high into the air, and eventually becomes all but lost in the clouds.
A great cheer rises up from the scattered  crowd. The festival is saved.

You find a folded piece of parchment.
Dearest Dace,
I understand what you're trying to do (in fact, I admire your ambition), but it doesn't matter how many times you ask. My answer is final. Under no circumstances will I allow you to leap out of The Swift mid-flight. That's not going to happen.
~ Ben Amon

The cloudhive dealt with, festival-goers emerge and assemble once more upon the grounds. Etra clears his throat and addresses the crowd. "Friends…I think this is as good a time as ever to bring this Blossom Festival to a close." The crowd is mostly quiet, but there are a few chuckles and some playful boos that lead to a unanimous, if somewhat sullen, applause. "Thank you one and all for attending!"

The cloudhive easily dealt with, festival-goers emerge from beneath tables and other improvised shelters, and the festivities begin once more. Despite the brief interruption, the festival goes on to be nothing short of a resounding success.
Even as the sun begins to dip below the western range, and the moon and stars appear in the sky, the festival continues. 
You find Etra and Raemon, laughing and enjoying a small cask of sunberry wine together . "Join us!" Raemon calls, raising his cup. "We were just giving thanks for such an incredible festival--bees and all."

"Many thanks to you as well," Etra says with a bow of respect. "Without your quick thinking, I imagine this place would still be swarming!" With that he excuses himself, and ducks into the main tent, then re-emerges holding a cloak crafted of leaves, vines, and flowers.
"It was made to be decorative," he says, handing it to you. "But watching you handle those bees, I imagine you could find all sorts of creative uses for it while you're out on patrol. May it bring you good fortune."
You thank Etra for the gift and clasp the cloak proudly about your shoulders.
As darkness falls and the lambance rigs are lit, you pause for a moment to look upon the festival grounds. There you see the people of the Valley, the people to whom you've dedicated your life as a Ranger, and it's medicine for the heart to see them gathered here, laughing and enjoying each other's company despite the events of the day.
With a satisfied sigh, you gather your gear and prepare for the trail.

Olyv's easygoing smile disappears when you withdraw Bo's letter from your pack and hand it to her.
"What's this?" she says, examining it closely. Then her eyes go wide. "This is from Bo!"

You watch as Olyv turns the envelope over and discovers that the seal is broken. You hold your breath. "I wonder what happened," she says absently. You shrug your shoulders in response, but she doesn't seem to notice. Her eyes are fixed entirely upon the envelope.

Timidly, as if she expects the letter inside to bite her fingers, Olyv opens the envelope, unfolds the letter, and begins to read.
You watch as tears well in her eyes. Then, she tips the envelope, and a small carbonforged pendant, made in the shape of a tortoise, falls into the palm of her hand.
Olyv stares in disbelief at the pendant for some time before gripping it tight in a fist. 
"Spawn of a mulcher," she says to herself. After a moment, she shakes her head as if to chase away a thought.
"I don't know what to say," she says, her voice faltering. You tell her that whatever she has to say, you're not the one she needs to say it to. 
"You're right, of course," she says. Olyv closes her eyes, holding the pendant tight. "I'll head to Spire as soon as I can," she resolves. "It's been far too long. I…need to talk to Bo."

Just as you are about to give up hope that you will ever find Bo's letter, you spot an envelope by the side of the trail and see the name Olyv Sol scrawled across the front. This must be it!
It's held shut by a wax seal. It feels like there's something else inside the envelope besides a letter; something small and heavy.
Now you just need to deliver the letter to Olyv. She's likely to be at Lone Tree Station, unless she's already earned her cloak, of course, in which case she'll likely be on patrol somewhere in the Valley.

You break the seal and open Bo's letter to Olyv. As you do, a carbonforged pendant in the shape of a tortoise fastened to a thin chain falls into your hand.
Dear Olyv,
I know it's been a while, and a letter from me is probably the last thing you expected or even wanted to receive, but I have to say something. I have to make amends in whatever way I can.
I was so angry and hurt when you decided to leave. It felt like you were abandoning me, but I know now that you were just following your heart, like the Elders teach us to. It wasn't right of me to get so mad, or to say the things that I said…that wasn't right, either.
The truth is, I've been a coward. I could have written you before. I could have even traveled to Lone Tree. I chose not to. I chose to stay here on my boat, wallowing in my misery. But I want you to know that I've finally come to my senses, and I have the pendant you gave me when we were kids to prove it.
As you can see, I found it. That night when we fought—when I off and threw it into the Silverfin—I wasn't myself, but then I saw the look on your face. I'll never forget it. You looked so devastated—like there was nothing worse that I could have done—and then you were gone. I felt like my heart had been ripped out. I thought about jumping in after it, but I knew that it had already been washed away by the current. So I just stood there and watched you go.
But then a couple days ago, what do I spot propped up in an artisan's stall like he made it himself? Your pendant. I couldn't believe it. I asked him where he found it, and he said it was at the bottom of a bundle of river stones he aquired from a merchant in Brookside. I had to trade half my stock of seasoned sitka jerky to get it back, but it was more than worth it.
I am so sorry, Olyv. I hope you can forgive me. I'll understand if you never want to speak to me again, but if there's any part of you that does, I hope you'll listen to that part, and come to see me while you're out on patrol. I'm at the docks most days, if I'm not out on the river. Or, if you send word, I'll happily make the journey to Lone Tree Station.
Your friend always, Bo

As you pick yourself up off the ground, you spot Bo's letter in the dirt, its seal broken. Thankfully, the letter itself is still in decent shape. You carefully wipe away the dirt before placing it back into your pack.

You find a letter held above the ground by blades of tall grass. It's emblazoned with the many-antlered emblem of the Terra Lodge.
Kordo,
You wanted me to let you know whether anyone ever brought in that horned garafon you tussled with a few years back? Well, it finally happened. A hunter by the name of Kasende, all the way up from Tumbledown, came through the door yesterday, calm as you please, garafon antlers in one hand, whispercrack darter in the other, and says, "Where should I put this thing?"
When I saw those antlers, why, I nearly fell over! I just knew it was your garafon. I could tell because the antlers still bore the scars from your gauzeblade!
I hope all is well at the Root, and that you're keeping your hunting skills sharp.
Spirits guide you,
Viv

The signs of Deadfall's rampage are readily apparent: trees with broken limbs lean to the left and the right of the trampled underbrush that marks her passage. Something has gotten her riled up, that much is for certain. But what?
Just then, you hear a low growl. You peek through the brush and spot the Great Ursus sitting with her back to a tree, gnawing at one of her hind paws. From your vantage point, you can clearly see the problem: a shard of kinetic glass from Tollin's broken scupture is embedded in her paw, no doubt causing her a great deal of pain.
As you come to this realization, she spots you, rolling back onto her feet and moving toward you with an angry growl. Your heart races. Wounded or not, she's still one of the most powerful and dangerous beings in the Valley.
You think, perhaps, if you can get close enough, you might be able to remove the shard of glass from her paw—assuming she will allow it, of course. As if in response, Deadfall rears onto her hind legs, as tall as an oak, and lets out a blood-curdling roar.

With a mournful groan, Deadfall slumps to the ground. Her rampage has come to an end, and while you may have completed your mission, a part of you wishes the outcome could have been different. Despite everything, she was a magnificent being. Though the inhabitants of the Valley will sleep better knowing they are safe, none will celebrate her passing. You bow your head in respect, and after a moment of silence, you dislodge the kinetic glass shard from Deadfall's great paw. The glass is cracked, but it's razor-sharp and still highly mutable. Perhaps you can find a use for it.

You approach the Great Ursus slowly and calmly. She paws at the ground and huffs, but you continue undaunted. You fix your eyes onto hers and perceive the embers of rage burning behind them. You take slow, measured breaths, keeping your heart rate steady as you draw closer, and as you do she seems to recognize that you're here to help.
She plops onto her rear with a grumble, and you very slowly reach for the kinetic glass shard embedded in her paw. It's wedged in pretty tight, and seems to be pulsing in the wound, but with some effort and careful timing, you manage to pull it out.
With a satisfied grunt, Deadfall rolls onto all fours, shakes her mountain of a body, and trots off. Now that the shard's been removed, you're confident that the wound will heal, and that Deadfall's temperament will improve.
You turn the kinetic glass shard over in your hands, examining it closely. The glass is cracked, but it's razor-sharp and still highly mutable. Perhaps you can find a use for it.

You smell the letter before you spot it. Dabbed with a fair amount perfume, its scent reminds you of cherrymoss blossoms and cinnamon stirred with honey. Inside is a love poem to the artist, Sil Belai, complete with a torrent of similes and overwrought adjectives. Perhaps it's a good thing this never reached her. Then again, maybe it's just the kind of thing she'd have appreciated.

You weren't sure what to expect when you arrived in Brookside, but it reminds you of a harvester anthill after a storm—every inch is alive and moving with a singular purpose. Preparations for the Blossom Festival are in full swing, and the thoroughfares are packed with people setting up tents and market stalls. In the center of the crowd is Etra Lash, shouting commands to a group of people attempting to stake down a rather large tentpole.
"No, not there, there!" he says, pointing to an empty plot some distance away. His eyes snap toward you as you step closer, and he flashes a broad smile. "Welcome, welcome! You're a bit early if you're here for the Blossom Festival," he says.

"I know your duties as a Ranger must take you all over the Valley, but I hope you're able to return and enjoy the festivities once we're underway," Etra continues. "It's shaping up to be quite the gathering!" Feeling inspired by the industriousness of the townsfolk, you ask if there's anything that you can do to help with the preparations. 
"That would be tremendous," he says. "I was actually getting pretty worried about wrapping all this up in time! We still need someone to gather flowers for the table arrangements, and to make matters worse, Raemon still hasn't arrived with the supplies or fresh fish for the feast from White Sky! Any help you could offer would be greatly appreciated." Without waiting for a reply, Etra turns back to the volunteers setting up the main tent. "That's it!" he cheers. "All together now…!"
You ponder the choice. Collecting flowers is likely something you can do while you're traveling all across the Valley, whereas helping Raemon deliver supplies will require you to travel to White Sky and back.

You find an unsealed envelope. The many pages within are written in a whimsical, unruly script accompanied by several simple drawings. Two stick figures stand at the bottom of the first page, one with a crudely drawn but impressive beard labeled "ELDER HALE," the other with what appears to be a large glove on one hand, labeled "ME."
Dear Elder Hale,
I did like you said and wrote down everything I could remember about my adventure in the Old Forest. It was hard! It's not hard to REMEMBER. I can do that! I just don't want to WRITE about it. I know you said it's important, but I still think it's more fun to just DO STUFF. Writing is SO BORING! Sorry, Elder! Anyway, here it is. I called it THE CHUBBY FROG AND THE BEARSLOTH WHO ATE HIM AND IT WAS SAD SO I CRIED.
SEE YOU NEXT TIME!
~ QUISI
You can't help but smile as you tuck the pages carefully into your pack.

You arrive to sounds of panic and terror. Villagers flee in every direction as rivers of reclaimers flow toward the spire. There's no time to waste. You must reach the village proper and aid in the evacuation before it's too late.

The Silverfin flows swiftly by, glittering in the sun as you make your way down the wooden stairs to the docks. Bright-winged birds circle high above, occassionally diving into the current to pluck a wriggling fish from the water.
Crowded piers extend out into the river, where several skiffs and seed barges are moored. The air smells strongly of fish. Dockworkers and river pilots are busy unloading the day's catch and loading up boats with goods bound for other villages along the river. From here, one could take a boat to and from the riverbank, or up and down the Silverfin itself.

A long bridge of gray stone arches over the glistening waters of the Silverfin—the only major crossing leading in or out of the bustling village of Spire. It's customary for travelers along the bridge to stop and greet one another as they pass. Several travelers are already engaged in lively conversation, in no particular rush to get to where they're headed.

On the outskirts of Spire, the riverbank is home to dozens of homesteads and lush gardens that, over the years, have accumulated into a small village. A cobblestone thoroughfare leads into the bustling neighborhood, punctuated by small footbridges crossing over the Silverfin's many tributaries. Along the path are several artisan workshops and cozy homes, as well as the occasional stilt-horse-drawn wagon loaded with goods for trade.

Brookside is still swarming with bees after the events of the festival. The massive cloudhive has settled over what was the festival grounds, and it doesn't look like it's going to be leaving anytime soon.
The Blossom Festival is well underway when you arrive. Throngs of people make their way to the festival grounds, chatting merrily as they go.

Amongst the hustle and bustle of the festival arrangements, you spot Etra Lash leading several others down the trail away from Brookside. It looks like he hasn't yet completed the festival preparations. "Hello again!" he calls out to you as he approaches. "How's your task coming along?"

You spot Etra escorting a crowd of villagers toward the festival grounds, gathering more and more as he goes. He waves, motioning for you to join him. "You are coming to the Blossom Festival, are you not?

You notice Etra Lash standing at a market stall by the side of the path, perusing some delicious-looking pastries. The smell of freshly baked bread wafts over to you from the market. Etra spots you as you approach and smiles amicably. "Hello there! Can't resist the scent either, eh?" he says with a chuckle.

As you walk down the path, you come across Elder Mora Orlin in the midst of a heated discussion with Etra Lash, the man who organizes festivals and ceremonies for the village of Spire. "It'll just be for a few hours, my dear Elder Orlin," Etra says pleadingly. "A day, at most!"
"Oh, for the love of the ancestors," Elder Orlin replies. "I'll tell you what. If you can find enough people who agree with you, then I will concede the point, but for now, my decision stands. Now, if you'll excuse me, I am expected at the Forge…" With that, Elder Orlin walks off brusquely, and you watch as Etra is left to sit with his thoughts.
"Not finished yet? Well, that's okay. There's still plenty to do," Etra explains. "If you want to help in some other way, you're more than welcome. What do you say?"

You see many familiar faces on your way to the festival grounds. The air is charged with excitement as the main tent comes into view. Etra stays behind and ushers everyone into the festival grounds, saying hello to each and every attendee, then heads off to shepherd more villagers toward the festivities.

"I'm headed to a meeting and wanted to bring some treats," Etra explains, wrapping some still-warm bread in cloth and placing the bundle in a basket. "As a Ranger, I'm sure you understand just how welcoming a basket of baked goods can be! Why, I remember meeting a Ranger on the path when I was just a boy. She stopped by say hello, and then offered me a biscuit. It was a little stale, but I remember it being quite delicious all the same." Etra looks off, wistfully, then returns his attention to you. "As a matter of fact…here," he says, gesturing toward the basket. "Please. I insist!"
You pluck a sweet roll from the basket and give thanks. Etra beams with delight, then departs with a wave.
Etra looks over the handful of villagers you've assembled and counts heads. "Hmm…could you maybe gather a few more people? Elder Orlin will surely need a greater consensus than this."

You return to Etra with a small gathering of villagers whom you've converted to Etra's cause.
"Well, would you look at that!" he says, wearing a proud smile. "You're more persuasive than I thought!"
He turns and addresses the gathered villagers. "Everyone, to the Carbon Forge!" and  together they march off to find Elder Orlin. You can tell from their enthusiasm that Etra is going to get his way.

You ask Etra what his argument with Elder Orlin was about, and he sighs. "You see, I would like to use the Carbon Forge to craft a few decorations for the event that's coming up, but Elder Orlin, in her wisdom, believes it to be frivolous. 'The Carbon Forge is for necessities only,' she says. But fun IS a necessity! It's my life's work, after all!" Etra says with conviction. "I pled my case, but it sounds like she'll only agree to let me use the Forge if I can convince a bunch of others that it's worth it, so we might convince her in turn. What do you say, my friend? Care to help me build the case for the necessity of fun?"
"I knew I could count on you!" Etra shakes your hand vigorously. "Come find me after you've gathered a few people. I'll go do the same."
A few nearby villagers help you set Etra down on a nearby bench. They stand around fretting nervously as you take out some medical supplies and start the arduous task of tending to his wounds.

An enormous clearing marks the site where Spire holds many of its festivities, from annual celebrations and holidays to local get-togethers and feasts. At the moment, it's a bit of a mess—it looks like the grounds are being prepared for a festival, but it's in utter disarray.
You watch as a group of volunteers struggle to construct an enormous tent that currently  lies collapsed on the ground; a lumpy mess tethered loosely to half-assembled tent poles.
The rest of the volunteers wait patiently nearby for the tent to be pitched. Tables carved from enormous dolewoods are set up all around the disheveled tent, cluttered with stacks of unopened crates.
It looks like there's a lot of work to get done. You consider giving the beleaguered volunteers a hand.

What was a complete mess when you first arrived has transformed into a beautifully decorated fairgrounds. The main tent now stands tall, the many tables surrounding it decorated with colorful fabrics.
The paths leading to and from the tent are lined with rows of evenly spaced lambance rods, each glowing with a warm and inviting light. A sweet fragrance drifts through the air, and vibrant butterflies and hummingbirds flit about the grounds, along with more than a few cloudhive bees.

You step back and take a moment to admire your handiwork. You've staked the main tent, creating the centerpiece of the festival. Now that the tent is up, the rest of the volunteers can start moving the decorations inside and clear off these tables. You get the feeling that the festival is going to be a big success.

You find Raemon near his hoversled with a checklist in hand, taking inventory of his goods. He smiles and waves jovially as he spots you in his periphery. "Well, if it isn't my old friend!" To your delight, he seems more well-rested and refreshed than when you last saw him.

As you round a corner, you come across an unmistakable sight: a caravan of wagons and stilt-horse-led carriages guided by Raemon, a well-traveled man who carries people and supplies to and from Spire, Crossroads Station, and the various other villages of the Valley. He waves you over as you approach, though you can't help but notice how exhausted he looks.

A box of supplies tumbles off of Raemon's hoversled and onto the ground. "Ah, sorry about this old thing," Raemon says, slapping the side of the sled. "It's not used to carrying this heavy of a load. Here, let me help you with that…"
You stay a while and listen to Raemon's tales about his most recent trip. "I actually have a bit of a surplus at the moment. Interested in taking a look? I still owe you for that drink!"

"Ah, so this is where you were taking me," Raemon remarks as you begin to climb the steps to A Hearty Brew. You tell Raemon that it's about time he took a well-earned break. Work is important, but our bodies and minds need time to rest and recuperate, too. He nods along, rolling his eyes but smiling despite himself. "I know, I know. You're right—a wisdom older than the Elders themselves. Well, lead the way, then!"
You get a round of drinks and sit together in the open courtyard. A talespinner sits in a nearby corner, strumming a quiet tune on his lute. Raemon leans back in his chair, takes a few sips of honey mead, and breathes a sigh of relief. "I have to admit, I needed this. Thank you for taking the time to bring me here. I appreciate it."
He raises his flagon and you clink yours against it. "To the Rangers," he says. You make a toast of your own, and together you sit in silence while the worries of the day float away like leaves in the autumn breeze.
You pause for a moment to see how Raemon is doing. He lags behind slightly, exhaustion catching up with him. "Where are we headed, anyway?" he asks, curious.

"Who, me? I'm doing fine," Raemon says, unconsciously rubbing his eyes. The dark circles under his eyes, his grimy clothes, and his frequent yawning tell a different story. He's likely been running caravans back and forth for days at a time without pausing to rest. Maybe you should encourage Raemon to take a break. In fact, you know just the place.
You tell Raemon to come with you. "Why, do you need help with something?" he offers. You decide not to tell him where you're headed just yet—he would only protest.

Raemon barely seems to register his injury at first, then he takes another step and the pain causes him to keel over. You catch him and lay him on the ground. "I've had worse," he sputters, but you know better than to let a wound like this go untreated. Over his complaints, you start the process. It'll take some time, but it's worth it to ensure he's okay.

Your heel crunches as you step on a piece of glass, and as you look up, you spot the reason why: just beyond the path, a kinetic glass sculpture stands in ruin by the side of the stone bridge, its vague form held together in mid-air, blown apart into thousands of glittering shards. Whatever this sculpture once was, it's impossible to tell now. It's difficult to see from this distance, but if you had to guess, it looks like it was trampled by something enormous. You'll have to get closer to investigate further.

You step carefully through the cloud of glass, covering your mouth and nose so you don't inhale any shards, and examine the remains of the sculpture more closely. The device that held the kinetic glass in stasis is still functional, which explains the floating glass. A few flecks of dried blood on a larger piece confirm your earlier suspicion. A living being did this—a big one. Just then, you hear a voice call out from behind you. "In case you're wondering, it was a model of Spire," the voice says.
You turn to face Tollin Lang, Spire's resident sculptor. He carries a bundle of sculpting tools—no doubt hoping to clean up this mess or restore his creation. You ask what happened, and he looks at you with a troubled expression.
"It was the Great Ursus! A group of teens came to tell me that they saw it happen. And they were laughing! Laughing! The nerve!" Tollin exclaims. "The hunters call her 'Deadfall.' They say she's so big she can knock down a tree just by looking at it! Ridiculous. Well, she did more than look at my beautiful sculpture, that's for sure. Can you believe it? There's no accounting for taste."
You've heard the stories. From what you know, Deadfall is enormous, easily twice the size of the average adult ursus. She could trample right over a dolewood sapling and barely feel the impact. If she's on a rampage, it could spell trouble for the entire Valley.

Tollin has set up a series of devices to pull the scattered kinetic glass shards from the air and collect them so nobody gets hurt.
"Hello again," he says distractedly, clearly focused on his work. "This is going to take a some time, I'm afraid. Care to lend a hand?" You spend some time helping Tollin gather kinetic glass from the air before moving on.

"Hey!" Bo calls out to you as he spots you walking along the docks. A smirk plays on his lips as he hops off his seed barge and onto the pier. "What are you doing back around these parts? Thought I might not see you again, what with you Rangers being so busy and all."
Just ahead, you spot Bo unloading his seed barge along the docks. He greets you in his usual gruff manner. "Found that letter yet?" he asks.

Spotting Bo Talos up ahead, you are about to call out to him to tell him the good news when you are suddenly pulled away by none other than his estranged friend, Olyv Sol. She leads you around the corner of a nearby building and starts pacing back and forth, sweat beading on her forehead. "I can't do it," she says. "I can't go through with it."
You tell Olyv it's going to be okay, and that you will be nearby, cheering her on. She shakes her head. "You don't understand. He was so mad last time. When I…when I left. What if we just end up arguing again?"
You remind her that Bo was the one who sent for her. Clearly, he's not angry any more. He wants to make peace. "I know, I know," she nods along. Can you just…go talk to him first? Let him know that I'm here?"

As you navigate the bustling docks, you find yourself watching the dockworkers go about their business, loading and unloading skiffs and seed barges. For a moment, you set aside the urgency of your task and daydream about where each boat might have come from, and where they might be headed next.
"It's not polite to stare, you know," a man's voice calls out to you from behind. You turn to face a well-built, muscular man with a hard expression, no doubt earned by years of working the docks, carrying heavy loads. You apologize and tell him that you were merely lost in thought.
"Well, I've had enough of a day without you standing in the way gawking," he says with a scowl, pushing you aside so he can reach his seed barge. He loads a crate of carbon-forged fishing gear onto the boat and you make yourself scarce, though you can't help but wonder what's got his feathers ruffled.

You sit by the water's edge and spend some quality time with Bo before continuing on your journey. He thanks you again for helping to mend his relationship with Olyv. Even though Olyv joining the Rangers disrupted their plans, their friendship is stronger now than ever before.
"Hey, since I got you here, want to take a look through some of my wares?" he asks. "I do owe you one, after all."

You assure Bo that you're on the lookout for his letter, and you'll recover it should you spot it.
"I wish I knew for sure where the courier dropped it, but I have no clue. All I know is that he lost more letters than just mine. He said the velox attack happened at about the halfway point of his route. Not sure if that helps, but that's all I know."

You tell Bo that you found and delivered his letter, and that Olyv wants to talk to him. His eyes go wide, and his usual hard expression softens as Olyv emerges from around the corner. You back up, giving the two some space.
For a moment, you think neither of them is going to speak. Then Olyv breaks the silence. "I…I got your letter," she says, quiet as a mouse.
Bo doesn't look her in the eyes, instead focusing his gaze on a thin carbonforged chain around Olyv's neck. A familiar tortoise pendant dangles on the end. "Olyv, I…"
"Don't," Olyv cuts him off. "You were right. We had all these plans, and I ruined everything."
"You didn't ruin anything," Bo says, gesturing toward the docks. "See? I'm piloting a seed barge, just like I always wanted. When you told me you wanted to join the Rangers, I was selfish and cruel. I was hurt, and I was just a big dumb idiot. I should have been happy for you. I should have said, 'Good for you!' But I didn't, and I haven't been able to live with myself since. Olyv, are you…happy?"
"I wish I could say that I was," Olyv confesses, tears in her eyes. "I love being a Ranger, but I haven't been able to live with myself either! I miss you, Bo. I miss our friendship." She steps forward slowly, cautiously, the space between them seeming infinite at first. Then Bo closes the gap and sweeps her into a crushing hug.
"I missed you so much," Bo says, his voice choked as the two embrace. You quietly step away and give the reunited friends some space.

You ask the man what's bothering him, which earns you a hearty chuckle. "Rangers really will help with just about anything, won't they?" he jokes. "Fine, take a seat."
He introduces himself as Bo Talos, a trader who travels up and down the Silverfin from White Sky to Tumbledown, mostly trading equipment and supplies between the various villages and homesteads along his route. "It was supposed to be me and my friend Olyv doing this together, but last year she just…abandoned all our plans and up and left for Lone Tree Station. She wants to be a Ranger like you.
"We haven't talked since that day. It…wasn't pretty. I said some harsh things I'm not proud of." He runs his hand through his hair and sighs. "I tried to apologize. I sent her a letter, but the courier came back to let me know that he'd lost it along the way. Said he was attacked by veloxes and his parcels all fell out of his satchel as he ran."
You ask why he doesn't try to send another letter, and he shakes his head. "You don't understand. It has to be that letter," he says stubbornly. "It's…special." Perhaps if you find Bo's letter, you can deliver it for him.
You tell Bo that you'll look for his letter and deliver it yourself. Bo raises an eyebrow. "You'd do that? Well…I'd be in your debt."

Bo staggers onto the ground, groaning. "Ugh…I thought I was tougher than this," he admits. You assure him that he is tougher than most as you sit down next to him, preparing to treat his wound. And it's true, too—he remains stoic throughout the process, not letting out a single grunt or complaint.

You almost don't spot Olyv before she swings down from a high tree branch, landing nimbly in front of you. "Hi there!" she says, beaming, resplendent in her gray ironwool cloak. She's clearly very proud of it, considering how well she's kept it since starting her travels as a full-fledged Ranger. "Where are you headed? Need any help from a seasoned veteran?" She lets out a lighthearted chuckle.

Ahead, you spot Olyv Sol sitting on a low branch overlooking the southern woods. Having gone through much of your training together, you remember Olyv well, but you also remember that during the Atrox Mountain night hike, an important exercise in every Ranger's training, she fell from a great height and broke both her legs. It was a sobering experience for everyone involved, and a not-so-subtle reminder that the life of a Ranger is often perilous.
Because of her injury, Olyv needed to spend many moons in recovery, and fell behind in her training as a result. It does your heart good to see her up and about again. She cautiously hops down as you approach.
"Hey! How's your patrol going?" she asks. "Must be nice to finally be done with your training, huh?" Her voice is tinged with a bit of envy.
"I have to admit, it feels great to be out in the wild again," Olyv says. "Mind if I keep tagging along?"

As you have been traveling with Olyv, you've noticed your shared mentor, Calypsa, secretly watching nearby, although Olyv seems oblivious.
"Well if it isn't Olyv Sol," Calypsa says, emerging from her hiding spot. "This is a surprise! I could have sworn that you had told me you were going to give up and go home. Yet here you are!"
Olyv does her best to mask her surprise. "Did I say that?" she replies playfully. "I guess I changed my mind."
"Nothing would make me happier," says Calypsa. "Are you finally ready to complete your training?"

"Ummm…," Olyv hesitates.
Calypsa raises an eyebrow. "I think you may need to spend some more time on the trail, just to be sure," she says.

"I am," Olyv says. "At least I think I am."
Calypsa smiles, but shakes her head. "I don't know, Olyv. You must be absolutely sure you still want to become a Ranger before you can swear the oaths."

"Yes!" Olyv says with confidence. "I am."
"Well, well!" Calypsa says. "It seems to me that you're finally ready to don the cloak."
"You better believe it!" Olyv says, beaming. 
"You have proven not only your resilience and understanding, but your dedication as well," Calypsa says. "I am so very proud of you." You can tell from her smiling eyes that she means every word. "Tonight, you will swear your oaths. Tomorrow, you will be a Ranger."
"Oh my gosh! Really??" Bursting with joy, Olyv floats over to you to give you a tight hug. "Thank you!" she says. "I'll never forget this." She gives you one more squeeze, then hurries off to prepare for the ceremony.

"Training is…well…it's been difficult," she says. "I've learned about as much as I can about being a Ranger. I've spent a lot of time in the library reading books and studying maps, but I haven't had the courage to go back out into the field since the accident." She lets out a long sigh. "Maybe Bo was right after all. I'm just not cut out to be a Ranger."
You tell Olyv that you're sorry to hear that she's having trouble, but that she shouldn't give up. It's surely only a matter of time before she's ready to get back out there.
"Maybe," she says thoughtfully, and at this a light seems to kindle behind her eyes. "Say, would you be willing to help me? You're right. I can't just sit around at Lone Tree Station for the rest of my life, but I'd feel a lot more confident if a full-fledged Ranger was by my side. What do you say?"

Olyv inhales sharply as she examines her wound. "Ah! That stings." 
You decide to use this moment as a teaching opportunity and tell Olyv to sit down so you can patch her up. Teaching her will take longer than simply dressing the wound, but this way you'll impart an important lesson on the fledgling Ranger.

You hear the Great Ursus's roar mere moments before she steps into view. The sound rattles your bones and sets your heart racing. The tales about the Great Ursus, Deadfall, don't do her justice. She's enormous—more than a thousand kilos of fur and muscle, nearly five meters tall, with claws that could strip the bark from a dolewood.
As she strides forward, you notice she seems to move with a bit of a limp. Even injured, however, she seems no less formidable.
Deadfall rears onto her hind limbs and roars once more, clearly enraged. What has her so worked up?
As you come to a clearing, you find yourself face-to-face with an animal and its offspring. You'll have to approach this situation with care. Parents are understandably protective of their young.
In between two buildings, you spot a narrow alleyway. It's a more direct, if somewhat less sociable, route through the village that could save you a lot of time if you want to avoid the crowds.
You slip into the alley, leaving the sounds of the bustling thoroughfare behind.
Despite all odds, Elder Orlin seems to be enjoying herself. A smile tugs at the edges of her mouth as she watches a group of children decorate a pool of water with floating flowers.

Dace stands just outside the main tent, quite literally bouncing up and down with excitement. "Wow! Look at all of this!" she exclaims, beaming. Spotting you nearby, she hops next to you. "Come on! Let's dance!"

You spot Tollin Lang by a field of tall grass, shouting to a group of children. "First to catch the scrof gets a treat!" He grins as you sidle up to him. "I've hidden a kinetic glass sculpture of a scrof in the field for the children to discover," he explains. "I call it 'The Great Scrof Hunt!'"
You find Etra Lash inside the main tent, proudly admiring his work. "Hello there!" he shouts over the din when he sees you approach. "I'm so glad you made it out to the festival!"
Bo Talos stands near a food stall, watching the proceedings with a scowl, though you suspect he may simply be putting on airs. Perhaps someone should encourage him to have some fun.

You spot Bo Talos and Olyv Sol standing together, enjoying some sweet honey rolls from a nearby trader's stall. "Mmm! This is so good!" Olyv says. "Come on Bo, you have to try one!" Bo sighs, but smiles affectionately. "All right, all right. If you insist!"
Raemon is helping a trader restock her stall when you approach. "Ah, hello there!" As usual, Raemon is working when he should be enjoying the festivities instead.
All of the villagers seem to be enjoying themselves in their own way. Some partake in the tantalizing array of food, while others dance and play festival games.

You watch as festival-goers take turns dunking their head in the water, laughing on their way back up. One emerges with several daisies stuck to her head, and the crowd rejoices. "The object is to catch as many flowers as you can on your way out," Elder Orlin says. "Come now, it's your turn!" She scoots you to the front of the line, and the next thing you know, your head is submerged.

Dace leads you to a clearing away from the hustle and bustle of the main tent, where a musical troupe of talespinners is playing the traditional tune known as "Ginny's Delight." You and Dace join the villagers dancing to the merry melody, and you swear sometimes the two of you lift off the ground as she twirls you around the clearing.

"All right, kids! New rule!" Tollin shouts as he pulls you to the edge of the field. A few curious heads pop out of the tall grass as you approach. "Now you have to find the scrof…while avoiding this agile velox!" He winks at you. "Well, what are you waiting for? Go get them, velox!" You roar, and the children flee, squealing with feigned terror.

You sit and converse with Etra for a while, letting your worries melt away. "Beautiful, isn't it?" he says, motioning to the gleeful crowd. Together you watch with smiles on your faces as the people of Spire dance, feast, and play.

You try to convince Bo to join the crowd, but he shakes his head. "That's okay. I'm having fun just watching. Honest." He lets out a wistful sigh. "Besides…the person I'd want to be with isn't here, anyway…" Despite his attitude, you get the feeling Bo is enjoying the festival in his own way. You spend some quiet time with him before rejoining the others.

Together with Bo and Olyv, you sample every one of the confectioner's pastries until all of you are stuffed. "I can't eat another bite," Bo says, patting his belly.
"Wanna bet?" Olyv grabs one more roll and playfully jams it against Bo's lips. The two of them fall into a fit of laughter as he attempts to fight off the pastry attack.

You tell Raemon that you'll help restock the stall in his place, and that he should go and enjoy himself. He protests, but eventually relents. Practically every time you see Raemon, he's working—it's nice to watch him unwind for once.

You spend time together wordlessly enjoying the festivities. The music is lively and the food is delicious. Before long, you part ways, smiling and laughing, as you each set your sights on the next diversion.

You kneel beside your charge and begin administering first aid, grateful that there are others nearby who can help. It takes some time, but thanks to the others, not as long as it otherwise would have.
You hear a shriek as a swarm of bees descends upon them. If you don't act quickly, they're surely going to come to greater harm.
You hustle them away from the festival until you're certain they'll be safe from the cloudhive swarms. You tell them to stay put before running back into the fray.

You remove them from immediate danger, but it's too late—they've been stung all over. You take some time to perform first aid on them, first removing the many stingers, then applying a cooling medicinal salve from your first aid kit.

You've counted many beautiful days in the Valley, but today is shaping up to be particularly stunning. A soft breeze plays across your skin, and the sun rises over the mountaintops, casting its golden light upon the newly bloomed flowers that cover the hillside.
Hummingbirds and cloudhive bees flit here and there among them. You can't remember seeing so many flowers in one place in your entire life.
"A glorious morning, is it not?" You're stirred from your reverie by a man's voice calling from the trail. You recognize Raemon from your travels—he often runs caravans of both supplies and people to and from Spire. He approaches your camp and shakes your hand in greeting. 
"It's always a pleasure to meet a Ranger on the trail. Looks like the weather is going to be perfect for the Blossom Festival, doesn't it? What good fortune!"
This is the first you've heard of a "Blossom Festival," but you're not surprised by the news. There's been abundant (and abnormal) floral growth all over the Valley for much of the current cycle, and Spire's Master of Revels, Etra Lash, is known to organize impromptu celebrations for occasions such as these. It is strange, you think to yourself, to see so many plants flowering at once—and so many out of season. You wonder aloud at the cause.
Raemon laughs. "I have responsibilites enough without troubling myself with such questions," he says. "But if you want to unravel the mysteries of nature, I wish you luck on your quest. May the ancestors guide you!" 
With that, Raemon waves goodbye and returns to the trail. You see him join up with a caravan of hoversleds and stilt-horse wagons traveling in the direction of White Sky.
As you prepare for the day ahead, you imagine the delights that the Blossom Festival might hold—honeyed sunberry wine, the luxurious sounds of a dolewood lute, specially prepared foods and confections created by Spire's most talented chefs…
…perhaps you should go to the festival grounds of Brookside, the small village on the riverbank across from Spire itself, to see how preparations for the festival are coming along. Rangers are tasked with aiding the people of the Valley in whatever way they can, after all. Maybe they could use a hand. 
You start down the trail, and watch as the cloudhive bees dance among the flowers.

If SPIRE FALLEN:
 You wake in a fret, your dreams haunted by terrifying visions. Your encounters with the reclaimers must have you on edge. But today is a new day—and an exciting one, at that. For despite the devastation caused by the reclaimer invasion, today is the day the Blossom Festival is set to begin in Brookside. You thought that perhaps the festival would be delayed on account of what happened in Spire, but the people are resilient and have already begun to rebuild. Perhaps a festival is just what they need to keep their spirits high.

Otherwise:
 You wake to the sound of birdsong and emerge from your tent, feeling refreshed. You smile as you remember that the Blossom Festival begins today in Brookside.

You awake feeling refreshed, greeted by memories of the Blossom Festival and how you averted disaster. Thanks to you, more people will remember how delightful and merry the festival was, instead of how a cloudhive swarm nearly ruined it.

You wake in a fit, only to discover that your nightmare about being covered by a blanket of angry bees was just that: only a nightmare.
You hope that the people of Brookside stay safe now that they have a massive colony of cloudhive bees so near to their village.

You pass by some travelers on the trail in the early hours of the day, and hear in passing that the Blossom Festival ended in ruin—apparently all of the floral decorations caught the attention of a massive cloudhive which now hovers ominously over the festival grounds in Brookside.
